post_text: Congratulations to Luther Burbank Elementary's Ross Hause - 2020-2021 Sonoma County Teacher of the Year. Administrators, teachers, family and friends wished him well in a socially distant ceremony today. We know his students are smiling, too! #SRCStogether
shared_text:
Sonoma County Office of Education
August 7 at 2:25 PM ·

Today we hosted a socially distanced outdoor celebration for the 2020-2021 Sonoma County Teacher of the Year recipient Ross Hause.

Ross Hause is a Santa Rosa City Schools sixth grade teacher at Luther Burbank Elementary School who has been instrumental in creating a Burbank Family where he says “kids feel safe with a deeper sense of belonging that drives them to work harder in their academics, and parents feel more welcomed and part of our school community.”

Santa Rosa City Schools’ Superintendent Diann Kitamura and Luther Burbank School Principal Debi Cardozo joined Dr. Herrington along with David Williams, chief marketing and human resources officer, from Community First Credit Union, to celebrate Mr. Hause.

In recognition of his achievement, Hause received a $3,000 award from Community First Credit Union and will be submitted as an applicant for the prestigious 2020-21 California Teacher of the Year award.

ETHNIC STUDIES WEBINAR: Our SRCS Board of Education recently approved the inclusion of Ethnic Studies as a graduation requirement by 2025. The Board also affirmed support of California Ethnic Studies Model Curriculum.
Today, State Supt of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond hosted the second in a series of virtual classroom sessions about ethnic studies (recorded webinar linked here).
Guests included Dolores Huerta, the labor leader and civil rights activist who, along with Cesar Chavez, co-founded the National Farmworkers Association.
Today’s event focused on the importance of ethnic studies in general, the history of Chicano Latino Studies, plus a lesson and activity within the discipline of Chicano Latino Studies, one of the four foundational groups of ethnic studies.
The series is designed to help students, educators, and families familiarize themselves with the core areas of ethnic studies, including how different groups have struggled and worked together, as well as key concepts such as equality, justice, race, ethnicity, and indigeneity.
#SRCStogether

June 12 at 3:17 PM ·

The Sonoma County Office of Education (SCOE), in collaboration with the Sonoma County Department of Health Services and a committee of regional superintendents, is releasing a document of guiding principles and planning considerations that schools and districts should consider when making plans for opening the 2020-2021 school year. It is important to note each district is responsible for creating its own reopening plan.

Read more about the guidance here: https://bit.ly/2XVDpK2

Roadmap to a Safe Reopening: Key Considerations for Sonoma County Schools to Address the Challenges of COVID-19 can be viewed online here: https://bit.ly/3dSNq0e

Questions and concerns about the guidance can be emailed to communications@scoe.org and will be responded to within 72 hours.

According to SCOE: "A total of 12 classified school employees were nominated by their school districts for the outstanding work they do in creating and maintaining positive school environments for the students of Sonoma County. Five were selected as finalists who will advance to the state-level awards contest. The state program is currently on hold as the state responds to COVID-19. However, SCOE wanted to be sure that Sonoma County nominees and finalists were honored before the end of the school year."
Thank you all for your service to our schools and families!
#SRCStogether

Sonoma County Office of Education
May 20 at 4:43 PM ·

In honor of Classified School Employee Week, SCOE is recognizing outstanding classified school employees from around the county.

Classified school employees, from school bus drivers to cafeteria workers to instructional aides, are the often-unsung heroes who play key roles in creating a school environment that contributes to the whole child by promoting student achievement, safety, and health.

A total of 12 classified school employees were nominated by their school districts for the outstanding work they do in creating and maintaining positive school environments for the students of Sonoma County. Five were selected as finalists who will advance to the state-level awards contest.

You can learn more about Sonoma County's finalists and nominees here: https://www.scoe.org/pub/htdocs/news-archive.html?news_id=1301

The designation is awarded to districts nationwide that demonstrate outstanding achievement in efforts to provide music access and education to all students.
Our community should know that, even during the shelter in place and Distance Learning, our student musicians, including those in the 4th-6th Grade Music Blitz program, have been invited to continue with their music through Google classroom. Our music teachers have been working together to create lessons and videos for the students, as well as ways for the students to play along with their peers in pre-recorded performances. We're proud of all of our student musicians, music teachers, and this honor!

Congratulations to Piner High School culinary students! Fifteen students, along with their advisors, Ms. McCabe and Mr. Rose, recently traveled to the regional FCCLA meeting and competitions in Santa Clara. According to Ms. McCabe: “We drove away with two 1st-place medals, a team 2nd-place medal, and two 3rd-place medals.” Congrats to: Jazzlyn Dowling, 1st place in wedding cakes (Japanese theme); Bao Nguyen, 1st place patisserie (Asian Tea Party with Matcha); the team of Yasmin Valadez, Yisel Aguilar-Magana, Giselle Soto, 2nd place Culinary Arts; the team of David Solis and Shane Canaday, 3rd place Culinary Arts; Emily Bundock, 3rd place wedding cakes (Dutch theme).
Also, anyone with a gold seal on their certificate earned enough points to participate at State. Those students include: Donovan Carrillo, Luis Luna,
Vanessa Romero, and Jose Ruiz.
Way to go! #madeinsantarosa #SRCStogether

Way to go, Piner High School GIS students! They ran education stations for elementary students yesterday for GIS Day 2019 at the Finley Center. Geographic information systems (GIS) technology has real-world applications. The Piner High students helped more than 220 elementary students at these stations:
1. A Geo-Cache course in Finley Park
2. Drone Demo, Map Gallery, Vendors, and Augmented Reality Sandbox
3. Mapping Exercise with Sonoma Water
4. Public Safety Demonstration with SR Fire and CalFire
According to Piner High Teacher Kurt Kruger, “My GIS group did an outstanding job sharing their knowledge with the elementary students. They worked hard for 4 hours straight. There is no greater compliment to a teacher than to have them step up and share their knowledge with young kids.”
This is the 9th time Piner students have run the educational side of GIS Day; the professional part is run by North Bay GIS User Group
#gis #mapping #madeinsantarosa #SRCStogether
